title: RL33165
content: The electric utility industry is a significant source of air pollution, including sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, and mercury, as well as carbon dioxide. The EPA released an analysis comparing different approaches to controlling this pollution, focusing on market-oriented mechanisms for cost-effective solutions. The analysis compared versions of the "Clear Skies" proposal with bills introduced by Senators Jeffords and Carper. The EPA's new analysis compares different versions of the "Clear Skies" proposal with bills introduced by Senators Jeffords and Carper, which impose more stringent requirements. The Administration initially resisted conducting the study due to cost and difficulty but relented after the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee failed to report the Clear Skies bill. Opponents of the bill cited the lack of a comparative analysis as a reason for its failure to advance. The EPA conducted a cost-benefit analysis of the Clear Skies bill and other Senate bills in response to concerns raised during confirmation hearings for EPA Administrator Stephen Johnson. Electric utility generating facilities are a major source of air pollution due to the combustion of fossil fuels. The combustion of fossil fuels in electric generating facilities results in air pollution, emitting gases like particulate matter, sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, and mercury. These pollutants pose direct risks to human health and welfare, with some gases also contributing to global warming. Regulations under the Clean Air Act control emissions of SO2, NOx, and CO2 from these facilities, with reductions seen in SO2 and NOx emissions. Table 1 shows the declining emissions of SO2 and NOx from electric generating facilities due to regulations, while CO2 emissions continue to rise. Fossil-fuel-fired plants accounted for a significant portion of the country's emissions in 2003, with Hg emissions from utility facilities being uncertain but estimated at around 45 tons. Emissions from U.S. fossil-fuel electric generating plants, particularly Hg from utility facilities, are estimated at about 45 tons, accounting for over 40% of the country's total Hg emissions. The evolution of air pollution controls has led to a complex system of regulations, with additional controls in progress for NOx, SO2, and PM 2.5 emissions. The United States is implementing additional controls on NOx, SO2, and Hg emissions, as well as voluntary limits on CO2 emissions under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. The Bush Administration rejected the Kyoto Protocol in favor of a voluntary reduction program, while the Senate passed a resolution in 2005 calling for mandatory controls on greenhouse gases. The Senate passed a resolution in June 2005 for mandatory controls on greenhouse gases, focusing on a "multi-pollutant" approach targeting SO2, NOx, Hg, and CO2 emissions from utilities to balance environmental goals with industry stability. The new approach aims to balance environmental goals with industry stability by implementing controls on pollutants like SO2, NOx, Hg, and CO2 emissions. This approach has already been integrated into existing law through rules such as CAIR, CAMR, and CAVR, which focus on capping emissions from coal-fired power plants and improving visibility around national parks and wilderness areas. The Clean Air Visibility Rule (CAVR), implemented in 2005, targets SO2 and NOx emissions affecting visibility in national parks and wilderness areas. Reductions in SO2 and NOx emissions are necessary to comply with new air quality standards for ozone and fine particles. Mercury emissions are also a concern, with 44 states issuing fish consumption advisories due to mercury contamination in water bodies. Mercury contamination in water bodies has led to fish consumption advisories in 44 states, covering millions of acres of lakes and river miles. Legislation addressing power plant pollution, such as the "Clear Skies" initiative, is being considered in Congress to achieve health and environmental goals more cost-effectively. In the 109th Congress, legislation known as "Clear Skies" aims to impose multi-pollutant controls on utilities, addressing SO2, NOx, and Hg emissions from electric generating facilities through a system of tradeable allowances. Key questions in the debate include the stringency of caps, the timeline for reductions, and the inclusion of CO2 emissions. The congressional debate on multi-pollutant controls focuses on the stringency of caps, reduction timelines, and inclusion of CO2 emissions. Bills require 70-80% reduction of NOx and SO2 emissions, and 70-90% reduction of mercury. The Clear Skies bill has the least stringent standards and longest phase-in period, with final deadlines set for 2018 but targets may not be met for a decade. The Clear Skies bill sets final deadlines for 2018, but 70% reduction targets may be delayed for up to a decade due to banking provisions allowing utilities to overcomply early on and use credits for later emission reductions. The Clear Skies bill allows banking of emission allowances, leading to potential delays in achieving 70% reduction targets by 2026 or later. Jeffords and Carper bills, with stricter caps, would enable utilities to reach full compliance at least a decade sooner. The Jeffords and Carper bills impose controls on carbon dioxide, unlike Clear Skies. This difference in regulation may lead to varied compliance strategies, potentially preserving a market for coal and reducing the reliance on natural gas or renewable fuels for power production. The EPA analysis compared six options, including variants of Clear Skies, Carper's Clean Air Planning Act, and Jeffords' Clean Power Act. The results showed little difference between the Clear Skies options, simplifying the discussion to three main choices. The Institute of Clean Air Companies (ICAC) questioned the EPA's assumption of limited boilermaker labor for constructing air pollution control equipment until 2010. ICAC conducted their own analysis and found no constraint on construction, demonstrating the industry's ability to install significant amounts of equipment in short periods of time. This was evidenced by recent installations of selective catalytic reduction controls in the US, Germany, and Japan. The installation of SCRs for NOx SIP call and control installations in Germany and Japan have shown the industry's ability to install air pollution control equipment efficiently. Clear Skies is highlighted as a cost-effective option compared to other bills, with minimal costs and benefits in the short- and long-term. Clear Skies is the most cost-effective option with less stringent requirements and later deadlines compared to other bills. It aims to revamp the Clean Air Act's structure with a focus on cost-effectiveness, resulting in lower benefits than other bills designed to reduce pollution faster. The Clear Skies bill is more cost-effective but offers lower benefits compared to the Carper and Jeffords bills, which have more stringent pollution caps and earlier deadlines. EPA estimates Clear Skies would provide $6 billion in annual benefits in 2010, while Carper and Jeffords bills would offer $51 billion and $83 billion respectively. By 2020, Clear Skies benefits almost merge with baseline increases, lagging behind the $19 billion and $66 billion annual benefits of the other bills. The Carper and Jeffords bills offer higher benefits due to more stringent pollution caps and earlier deadlines compared to the Clear Skies bill.
